Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Computing Cluster to Enable Transformative Research across Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Loyola University Maryland will acquire a computing cluster with central processing and graphical processing units (CPU and GPU). The computing cluster will be utilized for computationally expensive research projects spanning multiple fields, including computer science, materials engineering, electrical engineering, physics, chemistry, and economics. As a primarily undergraduate institution, Loyola is also committed to training the next generation of researchers via undergraduate research opportunities. Through the acquisition of its first major computing cluster, Loyola will expand opportunities to introduce undergraduate students to modern computationally-intensive tasks and multidisciplinary research, preparing them for graduate school and computational work within their chosen fields. Additionally, it will support projects within the university's new interdisciplinary Data Science M.S. degree program.

The initial eleven research projects will impact areas as diverse as software development, medicine, and social policy. Example impacts include developing techniques leading to drugs to fight SARS; understanding protein-DNA interactions for biotechnology applications; providing policymakers with a better understanding of how job competition and human capital allocation influence the optimal design of unemployment insurance; improving software quality by helping programmers identify and avoid the introduction of dependence clusters; improving techniques for coordination in pursuing a moving target, such as in military operations, autonomous automobile police chases, or surveillance programs; new methods for the creation of fossil fuel alternatives; providing secure communications for mobile devices in the Internet of Things; and improving techniques for nondestructive evaluation of electromagnetic materials, which is of critical importance in agriculture, bio-electromagnetics, aerospace, and the design of integrated circuits. This high performance computing cluster will significantly increase the shared computing resources on campus, thereby expanding opportunities for faculty research, faculty recruitment, and student research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2016 Loyola University Maryland was awarded funds to purchase a High Performance Computing (HPC) Cluster.  The acquired cluster includes 676 CPUs with over 7 terabytes of memory and 171 terabytes of disk space, all communicating over a 56 gigabit network and running the CentOS 7 version of the Linux operating system. The goal for this computing resource was to support faculty and student research broadly across the university, with a focus on supporting research in the natural and applied sciences, engineering, and economics. Success in achieving this goal includes projects involving the Sellinger School of Business, the Natural and Applied Science division, and collaboration between faculty in computer science and the Humanities. There are almost a dozen researchers from the natural and applied sciences benefiting from the HPC cluster. Additionally, the cluster supports collaborations with researchers from around the world.

Beyond the research projects it supports, the HPC cluster also had a direct impact on the education of ten Loyola students. Most of these students used the cluster over the summer in connection with Loyola's Hauber Summer Research program, while others used the cluster as part of class projects. Several of these students continued their work during the subsequent academic year, and at least a third of them plan to pursue their Ph.D. largely as an impact of their research experience while undergraduates.

The impact of the HPC cluster is evident in the sciences, but can also be seen across Loyola's campus. Example scientific impacts include improved testing of cryptographic algorithms aimed at protecting key information infrastructure especially in the post-quantum computing world, new techniques for improved software development, secure communications for mobile devices in the Internet of Things, and improved analysis of simulation models.

Considering one of these projects in greater detail, two Loyola undergraduates together with Loyola faculty and researchers at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, considered the movement of carbon nanotubes (CNT) in lipid membranes. Biological cell membranes, which are lipid bilayers, contain protein pores through which water, ions, and small molecules can pass. There is interest in understanding how carbon nanotubes mimic these pores. High-speed atomic force microscopy measurements showed that as the viscosity of the supported lipid bilayer increases, the diffusion coefficients of the CNTs decrease. Molecular dynamics simulations confirmed the experimental findings and revealed the formation of a lipid ring structure around the CNT. Potential applications are in the areas of drug delivery and biological sensors.

An excellent example of collaboration between the sciences and other departments is a project involving the philosophy department, in which a computer science summer research student used machine learning techniques to work on the segmentation and analysis of handwritten medieval text. Loyola maintains one of the largest digital databases of late medieval manuscript transcriptions in the country, and this project automatically correlates the lines of transcribed text to their geometric position on the original image. This mapping allows scholars to more easily switch from the transcription to the image and thus improves the work of all scholars whose work involves transcribed medieval texts, and shows the power of machine learning in advancing other fields.

Finally, the cluster was also critical for two projects within the business school.  In the first, Jeremy Schwartz and Andrew Samuel examine whether firms in more competitive industries engage in more earnings manipulation as well as choose poorer quality auditors to hide their manipulation. This project is the first work to address how competition impacts the joint decision to manipulate earnings and choose a high equality auditor. Using the HPC cluster the researchers empirically estimate a mathematical model. The results show that greater product competition reduces both compliance with accounting standards and the demand for high quality audits.

In the second project, Jeremy Schwartz explores the optimal design of unemployment insurance (UI) in the presence of human capital that increases with job specific experience and job competition between workers of differing skill levels.  The research develops a mathematical model where, in an effort to get back to work faster during recessions, high skilled workers may misallocate their labor to positions for which they are over-qualified, leading to a misallocation of human capital.  Given the complexity of the model the HPC cluster is necessary to feasibly simulate the model and run a variety of policy scenarios.  The results indicate that a UI system that becomes more generous during a recession increases welfare and better allocates human capital over the business cycle.

All of the research on the computing cluster has been published or is in the process of being published. Researchers at the university will continue to use this infrastructure beyond the end of the grant period.
